Pembina Midstream, USA Lynchburg Propane Terminal

Executive Summary



1.  Environment, Health and Safety (EHS) Policy



Pembina Midstream is committed to protecting the health and safety of all individuals affected by our activities.  We are committed to safeguarding the environment and contributing to the well-being of the communities in which we operate.



Pembina works to continually improve our EHS performance by:

A?    Integrating EHS best practices into all parts of our business.

A?    Ensuring compliance with applicable laws, regulations and industry standards.

A?    Identifying, assessing and managing EHS risk throughout our business.

A?    Ensuring that each employee, contractor and third party service provider understands their EHS responsibilities, is trained to meet them and is monitored for compliance.

A?    Establishing EHS objectives and regularly measuring our progress.

A?    Maintaining Pembina Midstream's commitment to open and honest dialog with stakeholders





2.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The function of the Lynchburg Terminal is the wholesale distribution of propane.  The propane is normally delivered by rail tank car, stored in nine 30,000 gallon capacity vessels and is distributed by customers trucks.  The one substance regulated under the Risk Management Plan (RMP) is propane.  The quantities of propane stored in each 30,000 gallon vessel are controlled to 90% of their capacity to prevent overpressuring.  This procedure is backed up by a system to prevent pressure exceeding 250 psi, preventing structural damage to the vessels and also preventing an uncontrolled release.  Based on the aforesaid, the maximum inventory in storage at the site is 9 times 27,000 gallons or 241,000 gallons equivalent to 1,027,112 pounds of propane.





3.  Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenarios



The parameters of the offsite consequences analyses for the terminal are based on the requirements set forth in RMP rules (40 CFR 68).  The wor

st case and alternate case radii of effect were determined utilizing RMP*Comp software.  The following describes the details:

A?    Worse case scenario for Program 3 involves a catastrophic release from one of the 9-30,000 gallon tanks in the propane storage and involves the release of the entire content of the tank (27,000 gallons or 114,124 lbs).  It is assumed that the entire quantity is released as a vapor, with 10% of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud explosion.  Off-site receptors would not be affected.

A?    Alternate release scenario for Program 3 involves a release from one of the propane storage tanks when a truck loading pipe/hose is ruptured releasing 49,000 lbs of propane.  It assumes that the entire quantity is released as a vapor with 10% of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud explosion.  Off-site receptors would not be affected.





4.  General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention 

     Steps



Pembina Midstream, USA has taken steps to comply with accidental release prevention requirements under 40 CFR Part 68. The facility is also subject to OSHA Process Safety Management 29 CFR 1910.119.  The following briefly describes the elements of Pembina Midstream, USA release prevention program for the Lynchburg Terminal:

(a)  Safety Information

Pembina Midstream maintains written information on chemical hazards, operating procedures and equipment associated with terminal operations.

(b)  Process Hazard Analysis

Pembina Midstream ensures that the hazards associated with terminal operations are identified and controlled.  The A?What If?A? methodology has been used in the process.  Identified issues have been addressed.  Pembina Midstream will continue to review operations on a regular basis and make improvements as appropriate.

(c)  Operating Procedures

Pembina Midstream has written operating procedures which cover among other things safe operations, emergency shut down, normal shut down

and start up.  This information is regularly reviewed and accessible to all operators.

(d)  Training

Pembina Midstream training of terminal staff is such to ensure safe operation of the facility and protection of staff, contractors and public.  New employees receive basic training in facility operations followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently.  Refresher training is provided as needed.

(e)  Mechanical Integrity

The integrity of mechanical operations is ensured through documented maintenance checks on major equipment.  Process equipment examined includes, among others:  pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valves, emergency shut down systems, controls, meters and pumps.  Maintenance is carried out by qualified personnel at all times.  Any equipment deficiencies are carried out in a safe and timely manner.

(f)  Compliance Audits

Pembina Midstream will conduct periodic audits at the terminal to ensure the provisions of the RMP rules are implemented at least every three years as required under 40 CFR 68.58.  Any shortcoming will be corrected in a safe and timely manner.

(g)  Incident Investigation

Pembina Midstream investigates any occurrence that could have or has resulted in a major release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to an incident or potential incident as well as corrective action required to prevent a reoccurrence.  All reports are retained for a minimum of five years.  

(h)  Employee Participation

A successful RMP is a team effort and the terminal staff is an integral part of the team and is encouraged to express their views. In addition, each terminal employee shall have access to all information created as part of the implementation of the RMP, in particular, information relating to and resulting from process hazard analysis.

(i)  Contractors

Periodically Pembina Midstream hires contractors to do specialized maintenance.  Each co

ntractor is evaluated for safe performance of activity to be undertaken and fully familiarized with Pembina Midstream safety requirements before coming on site.  Furthermore all contractors are informed of emergency response procedures should an incident occur.





5.  Five Year Accident History



There have been no reportable accidental releases over the part five years at the terminal.





6.  Emergency Action Plan



A written action plan to deal with accidental releases of regulated substances and other incidents is maintained at the terminal.  The plan includes mitigating actions, medical treatment, evacuation, notification of responders, affected parties and public.  To ensure proper response an emergency response team is always in place and equipment regularly inspected/serviced.  The RMP is fully coordinated with the Campbell County LEPC and the local fire department.



Pembina Midstream will continually monitor the implementation of its RMP in order to prevent accidental releases of propane and will update the plan as new circumstances arise or new technology becomes available.





7.  Conclusion



To our knowledge, Pembina Midstream has taken all steps necessary to be fully compliance with EPA and OSHA regulations to continue safe operation of the Lynchburg Terminal.  The information submitted herein updates previous information submitted on the facility that Pembina Midstream fully embraces.  Pembina Midstream is committed to the safety of all its stakeholders, public and employees and has endeavored to put in place measures to fully protect the aforesaid.
